docs.lead_paragraph: Looking back, Denise Watkins is convinced a sore throat disabled her son one year ago. His bizarre obsessions emerged not long after, first the constant nightmares about snakes and alligators, then the relentless hand washing that left his skin raw and chapped. Mrs. Watkins, who lives in Lakeland, Fla., was told that her son, Will, had obsessive-compulsive disorder. But it seemed odd, Ms. Watkins thought. Will was only 5 years old, and his illness seemed to burst out of nowhere.

headline.main: Can Strep Bring On An Anxiety Disorder?

docs.abstract: Condition Pandas, pediatric autoimmune neuro-psychiatric disorder associated with streptococcal infection, is believed to occur in one out of 1,000 children; symptoms include rapid change in child's behavior following or during strep infection; some studies support use of antibiotics to reduce effects of illness; Dr Susan Swedo, National Institute of Mental Health researcher who first described Pandas, believes it is caused by severe immune reaction that leads to brain damage; others hold that disorder is triggered by illness, but not directly caused by it; treatments discussed (M)
docs.snippet: Scientists know so little about a disorder that links a strep infection with obsessive-compulsive disorder in children that some question whether it even exists.

docs.lead_paragraph: Anger appears to have a bigger effect on the onset of strokes than positive emotions, according to a study released yesterday. The study also found that other negative emotions, in addition to sudden movements, like responses to startling events, appeared to act as triggers.

headline.main: Chill! You'll Give Yourself a Stroke

docs.abstract: Dr Silvia Koton of Israel Center for Disease Control leads research published in journal Neurology that indicates negative emotion, such as anger, is potential trigger for stroke; research finds that overwhelming positive emotions do not appear to impact risk for stroke; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Anger appears to have a bigger effect on the onset of strokes than positive emotions, according to a study released Monday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Lead exposure over the course of a lifetime appears to play a significant role in increasing the risk of age-related cataracts, a study has concluded. The study, published last week in The Journal of the American Medical Association, drew on data from 642 men enrolled in a long-running study of normal aging.
docs.abstract: Dr Debra A Schaumberg of Brigham and Women's Hospital (Boston) leads study published in Journal of the American Medical Assn that suggests lead exposure increases chances of developing age-related cataracts (S)
docs.snippet: Lead exposure over the course of a lifetime appears to play a significant role in increasing the risk of age-related cataracts, a study has concluded.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN MEDICAL ASSN

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Heart attacks are more common during the holidays. THE FACTS -- The stress of last-minute shopping, squabbling in-laws and busy airports can make the holidays more a season of headaches than of celebration. But is there any connection between holiday stress and heart attacks?
docs.abstract: Studies show that people are more likely to die of heart disease and other medical conditions during holiday season; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: The holidays can be more a season of headaches than of celebration. But is there any connection between holiday stress and heart attacks?

docs.lead_paragraph: Cutting out sleep appears to make it harder to cut out calories, two studies released last week suggest. In one study, published in The Annals of Internal Medicine, 12 test subjects were restricted to four hours of sleep two nights in a row. Their levels of a hormone that increases appetite rose by 28 percent while a hormone that suppresses it fell by 18 percent. At the same time, the subjects, 12 young men, reported increases in their desire for food, particularly for high-calorie, high-carbohydrate choices.

headline.main: Curb Your Craving: Sleep It Off

docs.abstract: Dr Eve Van Cauter, University of Chicago researcher, leads study published in Annals of Internal Medicine that shows lack of sleep causes body to increase levels of hormone that triggers hunger and suppresses hormone that reduces appetite; suggests that decrease in amount of sleep for average American may have impact on increase of obesity in United States; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Cutting out sleep appears to make it harder to cut out calories, two studies released last week suggest.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sitting in a small evaluation room at the University of Washington, apprehension written on her face, Christa Zamora turned her eyes toward her son Connor and contemplated his future. A talkative and animated 2-year-old, Connor appears normal, Ms. Zamora said, but it is too soon to be certain. Doctors diagnosed autism in her older son, Cameron, just before he turned 3. And with Connor, who is also at risk for developing the devastating neurological disorder, which runs in families, she has decided to be proactive, enrolling him in an early diagnosis study for children as young as 16 months.

headline.main: In Autism, New Goal Is Finding It Soon Enough to Fight It

docs.abstract: Autistic children diagnosed during early stages of disorder have better chance of overcoming debilitating effects of condition; growing number of children are being diagnosed before age two; Dr Geraldine Dawson, University of Washington's autism center director, and other researchers hope to soon develop ways to diagnose autism at birth using genetic markers and other diagnostic tools; early signs of autism are sometimes slight and pediatricians have been hesitant to send children to specialists before they are certain of problem; Dawson asserts that parents need to play larger role in getting early help for their children; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Across the country, thousands of toddlers are joining studies that could signal new hope for a baffling childhood disorder.

docs.lead_paragraph: Men would rather marry their secretaries than their bosses, and evolution may be to blame, psychology researchers at the University of Michigan reported last week. The study, in which college undergraduates were asked to make hypothetical choices, suggests that men in search of long-term relationships prefer to marry women in subordinate jobs rather than women who are supervisors, said Dr. Stephanie Brown, a social psychologist at the University of Michigan's Institute for Social Research and the report's lead author.

headline.main: Glass Ceilings at Altar As Well as Boardroom

docs.abstract: Dr Stephanie Brown, Institute for Social Research social psychologist at University of Michigan, leads study that shows men prefer to marry subordinates not bosses; study, which is published in journal Evolution and Human Behavior, was conducted with men and women, but unlike men, women did not generally change their view of possible relationship based on workplace status; Brian Lewis of University of California, Los Angeles, who co-authored study, suggests evolutionary reason for men's decisions (M)
docs.snippet: Men would rather marry their secretaries than their bosses, and evolution may be to blame, psychology researchers reported last week.

docs.lead_paragraph: Respiratory syncytial virus, or R.S.V., is an extremely common infection in children, second only to the common cold. Yet few parents have ever heard of it, at least not until someone in the family develops a serious infection from it. Maysa Leak, a jazz vocalist, knew nothing of it until doctors diagnosed a life-threatening infection with this virus in her prematurely born son before his first birthday. The baby recovered in the hospital, and Ms. Leak has since become a national spokeswoman, determined to raise awareness and educate parents about this disease.

headline.main: Masquerading Virus Preys on the Weak

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column describes respiratory syncytial virus and its adverse effects on children and elderly; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention data estimate that 125,000 children are hospitalized with serious RSV each year and 500 die from illness; high cost of preventive medicines keep all but those in serious risk of contracting RSV from obtaining pre-emptive treatment; symptoms and treatment of RSV, which is highly contagious, discussed; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Respiratory syncytial virus is an extremely common infection in children, yet few parents have ever heard of it.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: There were eight of us crowded into the exam room as an exasperated patient and I tried to figure out why he was feeling weak and tired and itchy and nauseated and almost fainted in the subway Thursday night. Two of us, the patient and I, were human beings. The rest had no voices, bodies or personalities in the ordinary sense of the word, but they played a role in the discussion that was just as vigorous and important as if they did.

headline.main: We Love Them. We Hate Them. We Take Them.

docs.abstract: Abigail Zuger essay describes limitations and expectations associated with taking prescription drugs; says that not every medical condition can be cured with medication and doctors and patients sometimes differ in what they think is best course of treatment; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: The relationships we all have with those little pieces of matter, our pills, are becoming ridiculously tangled.

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors are irate over malpractice. But they have not yet gone as far as Shakespeare, who suggested killing all lawyers. Still, at a meeting of the American Medical Association last summer, a surgeon from South Carolina proposed that doctors not treat lawyers who sue doctors. And while calmer voices dismissed the proposal, it highlighted the friction between lawyers and doctors that sometimes strains the patient-doctor relationship when lawyers seek medical care.

headline.main: Take Two Torts and Call Me in the Morning

docs.abstract: Growth of malpractice cases in United States has prompted some doctors to refuse to treat lawyers; American Medical Assn says that there is malpractice crisis in 20 states and cites evidence of doctors refusing to perform some high-risk services because they are afraid of litigation; Dr W L Wells Edmundson, who is Sen John Edward's physician, discusses treating high-profile lawyer with history of trying medical malpractice cases; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The friction that sometimes strains the patient-doctor relationship when lawyers seek medical care is at an all-time high.
